title: How to Measure Bar Stools

methods.name: Choosing Bar Stools of the Right Height

steps.headline: Check the distance from the floor to the underside of the bar countertop.
steps.description: Extend the end of a tape measure straight down to the floor below the bar. Read the number on the tape measure where it meets the underside of the bar counter to find the height. Standard bar countertops are usually 42 in (110 cm) high, while regular countertops are typically 36 in (91 cm) high. Always measure before you purchase bar stools to make sure you get the right height.

steps.headline: Measure from the floor to the top of the seat to find the height of bar stools.
steps.description: Stretch out a measuring tape from the floor to the top of the bar seat against the side of the stool. Read the number on the tape measure where it lines up with the top edge of the seat to get the height of the stool. Standard bar stools are generally about 30 in (76 cm) tall, whereas counter stools are usually around 24 in (61 cm) tall. Keep this in mind if you are searching for stools online so you can search using the right keywords.

steps.headline: Choose stools that will leave 10–12 in (25–30 cm) of space under the counter.
steps.description: This is enough space for comfortable sitting room. Chairs that are lower will make it awkward to sit and reach the bar, and chairs that are higher will make it tight and uncomfortable.Tip: If you are shopping for bar stools in person, then bring a tape measure with you to check the height of the stools. If you are shopping online, then make sure to look at the measurements before ordering any stools. For example, if you have a bar with a standard 42 in (110 cm) height, then you would want to choose stools that are 30–32 in (76–81 cm) tall.

methods.name: Calculating How Many Bar Stools You Need

steps.headline: Measure the length of your bar countertop in inches.
steps.description: Stretch a tape measure out straight along the edge of the countertop where you want to place the bar stools. Read the number in inches where it meets the end of the countertop. You only need to do this if you want to fit the maximum number of stools at the counter that you can comfortably fit.

steps.headline: Divide the length of the countertop by 28.
steps.description: This is a comfortable distance in inches to have from the center of the seat of 1 stool to the center of the seat of the next stool so people will be seated comfortably at the bar. Use a calculator to help you divide the length of the countertop by 28 to get an exact number. For example, if your countertop is 90 inches long, then you would divide 90 by 28 and end up with 3.2.

steps.headline: Round the number down to figure out how many stools you need.
steps.description: Always round the number of stools down to ensure a comfortable fit. It’s better to have too much space than to have people crammed at the bar next to each other.Tip: Rounding down will also leave you some extra room to account for anything like brackets or hardware under the bar counter that you can’t place stools directly under. For instance, if you get 3.2 when you divide the length of your countertop by 28, then round it down to 3 and get 3 bar stools for the bar counter.

steps.headline: Choose stools with backs and footrests if you will spend a lot of time at the counter.
steps.description: Bar stools with backs are more comfortable for bar counters that you will be eating or hanging out at, such as a bar counter attached to a kitchen. Footrests also add comfort to stools that you will sit in frequently and for longer periods of time.Tip: If you are getting bar stools for a countertop at your home and you have children, then consider getting some that have footrests at different heights or adjustable footrests to accommodate everyone. If your bar counter has a bracket near the floor at the bottom for a footrest, then you don’t need to get stools with footrests.

steps.headline: Get stools without backrests to save space.
steps.description: Stools with just a seat will allow you to tuck them all the way under the bar to save room when you aren’t sitting on them. This works well in smaller spaces, such as a studio or small apartment, where you need to make the most out of a limited amount of room. Keep in mind that square bar stools usually take up less room than round bar stools. If you will be sliding the bar stools in and out a lot, make sure the bottoms of the legs have protective caps on them or stick some felt furniture protectors to the bottoms to protect your floor from scratches.

steps.headline: Match the bar stools with the counter and the decor of the room.
steps.description: Choose colorful, decorative bar stools for bars that are muted and simple in color and design. Get more minimal bar stools if the bar counter is already colorful and has a lot going on design-wise. If you have wood floors or wooden furniture in the room and you get wooden bar stools, then try to match the color of the wood as much as possible.
